bibl.title: Notes from Liberian Legation In U.S. to Department of State, 1862-1898 T807

body.div1:
Sir,
In the short interview with which you honored honored me on Friday last. I informed you that had been commmissioned by the President of Liberia to apprehend your government with the hope that you would be indiced* to make in----- on con--- will prevent foreign chaos from making approachments* on our territoty.
Unfortunetly for me, the presence of business did not permit of your giving me time to lay the *faito before you and you told me to call the next day, which I did and called again on the following Monday and Tuesday; but with no better success coming to the great pressure of business in youir office.
As I had to leave your city, on Tuesday last *Li bold adopts this method of laying the matter before you, trusting that you will be kind enough to give it your consideration.
In the year 1885 a French Man of War came in to the harbour of our caprifal**, Monveria and the Revenue
The Honorable James G. Blaine, Secretary of State Washington D.C.
mander?*
mander?* cat upon the President. During the conversation the commander said that he had stopped at *Rerseby- a place within our boundray line and had an interview with the chiefs. The President said Why did you open there and have that interview? Do you not know that territory belongs to Liberia?" The commander replied that he did not know it belonged to Liberia and that he had been his** by his government stop these and have that interview.
After the departure of the vessel, the President said our representative in Paris to call the attention of the French Government to thr action of their office and to point out the fact that our boundary in the Southeast extended to the Ban Pedro Riveria as you will see by referring to the Imperial Atlas in your office and that they had virtually admitted it by their Natural Chant* amd otherwise.
Thw French Government then claimed that they had commercial treaties with the chiefs of Berrby* as old as 1846- I think; but we have been of Cession* of that territory made to us far back as 1836, **
We laid this matter before your government and dusted for your kind offices; and in a Despatch to W. M. Lean dated, Janurary 13th, 1886, W. Bayand instilled here to interview and to say to the French Government "We exercise no protection over Liberia; but the circumstances , the Republic *niginated thpugh the colonization of American citizens and was established under the festering sanction of this Government give us the rights as the next friend of Liberia to aid her in preventing any encrodment** of foreign powers on her territorial soverneignty and in settling any dispute that may arise. The Southeastern boundary at the River San Pedro has (?*MA) been questioned and the powerful sanction of general admission for many years".
The matter has remained in (*abeyamceas) we cupped* since that time; but it lately came to our knowledge that one Captain Binger- who was a permeant officer in the late expedition against the King of Duhouoey -- claim to have made explorations in the near and Southeast of Liberia and he has published, in a "Supplement Le Temps Mans 1890, a mafu** refreshing Liberia as a very Manrew** eefiq* along the coast, represneting the country in the immediate near of Liberia as far as Musandar** explored" country and liable to become a Protectorate of France,-- although our W.B. Anderson had explored that country as far as *Musardin and published an account of this journey and cutting off our territory on thr Southeast up to the Cavalla River thus taking the very territory in dispute and which in Bayaid says belongs to us by "the powerful sanction of general admission for many years". The territory was taken from is in represented in his map of French Senitor
Whilst the French have not as yet made an appearnoment** towards taking posession of the territory yet, the Secretary under the circumstances we feel
warran
warran**----(line unclear) Friend" and asking you to make such a demenstration in our favor as will prevent Foreign Governments from making and encrachment** on the territory. If your powerful Government would make us a present of one of your smallest steam-gunboats to be used in guarding our coast from foreigners and preventing them from settling
